body:
@anuraaga 
Thanks again
I have tested my running environment
The problem has been solved

ES_TIMEOUT is set to 60s
Could we link the issue that removed the minimap just to make it easier to follow the trail?
This sounds like a good UX improvement and a natural scenario a user would have.
Makes sense, i think it was contained in one of @tacigar big UI revamp issues but can't seem to find it.

>  3. A log is easily saved, copy/pasted, emailed, etc while the traces displayed in Lens are not

I would just add that traces can be downloaded in JSON format and passed around about as easy as logs.

> If timestamps are not set for some spans, it seems that UI cannot handle it well.

I agree it isn't good for the UI to fail to render entirely, but I'm wondering if there's an instrumentation bug or some other reason why some of the spans don't have a timestamp. From the [API documentation](https://zipkin.io/zipkin-api/#/definitions/Span) on the `timestamp` field:

> Epoch microseconds of the start of this span, possibly absent if
> incomplete.
> 
> For example, 1502787600000000 corresponds to 2017-08-15 09:00 UTC
> 
> This value should be set directly by instrumentation, using the most
> precise value possible. For example, gettimeofday or multiplying epoch
> millis by 1000.
> 
> There are three known edge-cases where this could be reported absent.
> 
>   * A span was allocated but never started (ex not yet received a timestamp)
>   * The span’s start event was lost
>   * Data about a completed span (ex tags) were sent after the fact

Maybe this is the type of situation we should give an indication in the UI that the data should be looked at to determine why it is missing generally expected elements.

Agree with Tommy. This is not normal situation, this could happen either in a bug in instrumentation or a misuse of the tracer (I have seen some instrumentation creating spans for things that should be logs). In either case we should warn the user.
Thanks for reporting, the intent was definitely not to have those metrics for static resources but I think might have broke in a refactoring. Will fix it to only track API

These were dropped when we switched away from Log4J2 for logging. Our intent was to have the dashboard updated to not have the logging metrics because we almost never log anyway.

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/2905#issuecomment-548995852
Ok! Want me to update dashboard?
I have gone ahead and removed tests that checked for metrics for not-found URLs and redirects - they don't seem that useful.

After I execute JAVA_OPTS='-Djavax.net.ssl.keyStore=elastic-certificates.p12 -Djavax.net.ssl.keyStorePassword=123456 -Djavax.net.ssl.keyStoreType=PKCS12 -Djavax.net.ssl.trustStore=elastic-certificates.p12 -Djavax.net.ssl.trustStorePassword=123456 -Djavax.net.ssl.trustStoreType=PKCS12' KAFKA_BOOTSTRAP_SERVERS=172.17.2.154:9092 KAFKA_TOPIC=bos-dev-zipkin STORAGE_TYPE=elasticsearch ES_HOSTS=https://172.17.2.154:9200 ES_USERNAME=elastic ES_PASSWORD=123456 EX_INDEX=bos-dev-zipkin java $JAVA_OPTS -jar zipkin-server-2.19.1-exec.jar and visit http://localhost:9411/zipkin/api/v2/services

The command looks fine - there are any number of reasons that could cause handshake failures such as expired or incorrect certificates, so it's always hard to pinpoint one. Does this only happen in a particular version of zipkin or even in older ones? Also, are you using Java 11? If so, can you try with the system property `-Dcom.linecorp.armeria.useOpenSsl=false` and see if anything changes?
@mstaalesen please do, I'll be happy to review. Thanks!

Hi, it looks like you are building a custom zipkin server. Unfortunately we cannot provide support for custom servers, we are a small group of volunteers and custom servers can have so many variables that it is too big of a burden on our community.

Did you know there are pre-built distributions of zipkin? Please check out our documentation for more information: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-server/README.md

If this is not the case please let us know, we are available by chat at https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin

I am curious about this use case @f0y and please correct me if I am wrong. If there are more than one root span in a trace, maybe it is a instrumentation issue? If the new spans come from outbound propagation, that is certainly an issue (at least on b3) because spanId is required. If new root span is a local one, then that is also an issue as the usual practice is to start a whole new trace. Could elaborate a bit more on the use case?

Thank you for your report.
I think showing up orphaned spans as siblings to the root span is most reasonable.

![show-ellipsis](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19551419/71537664-9154a980-2962-11ea-9f04-0e4659128920.gif)

I was able to display ellipsis in SVG, but for traces with about 1000 spans, the rendering speed is too slow. Probably this is caused by `ResizeObserver`.

I think virtualizing the trace graph may help avoid this. I will investigate it.

Probably, not work.
In svg 1.1, `text` element does not seem to support `text-overflow` attribute.

This feature may be introduced in svg 2.
https://www.w3.org/TR/2018/CR-SVG2-20181004/text.html#TextOverflowProperty

Virtualizing the trace tree is a very high cost for implementing.
So I tried optimization by using Intersection Observer API.

Large traces are now drawn relatively smoothly.

Apologies if this is a double comment I thought I sent it but can't find it.

By the way, for a future PR, what do you think of migrating from SVG to normal DOM + CSS? In the past SVG or Canvas were fast but I find that currently, it's hard to beat just normal HTML since it's what browsers optimize for. With flexbox, a lot of the reason to use non-dom went away, and we're paying the price of not using modern CSS.

I currently agree with using normal DOM + CSS instead of SVG.
Drawing trees with DOM + CSS is a bit difficult, but it is possible.
And, there is a possibility that the number of DOM elements will be huge due to the drawing of the tree, but virtualizing the graph using react-virtualized etc. will get rid of this problem.
So I'll close this PR, and will try to re-implement the trace graph component with normal DOM + CSS.

I'm really sorry 😭 
I made a mistake.

I investigated code which builds trace tree.

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/8a5609a44ea52fa85d5309d7e4e46bc70a4c3ca8/zipkin-lens/src/zipkin/span-node.js#L272-L276

In the current implementation, all orphaned spans will be children of the root span...

Jaeger can integrate with Zipkin instrumentation at the collection API, i.e. `jaeger-collector` can accept spans in Zipkin format (json, thrift, and proto). But it does not integrate with implementation details of Zipkin such as storage formats (or even query service API) because of the difference in the data models.

I still don't know the best way to draw graphs which contains orphaned spans.
However, according to the code comment above, I think that orphaned spans should be drawn as children of the root span anyway.
Of course, the current behavior when collapsing orphaned spans is a bug, so I will fix it first.

> Jaeger can integrate with Zipkin instrumentation at the collection API, i.e. `jaeger-collector` can accept spans in Zipkin format (json, thrift, and proto). But it does not integrate with implementation details of Zipkin such as storage formats (or even query service API) because of the difference in the data models.

You mean Jaeger collector can collect the data reported by Zipkin, but their data model is different.

Now, I use Zipkin client to send data to Kafka (HTTP is not allowed by the company), consume Kafka data through Jaeger server, and then store it in ES. Finally, use the Jaeger UI to show it. Is this solution OK?

Is there another better solution? Thank you very much.

I'm going to close this issue here as the ask is now outside the scope of the Zipkin ecosystem. 

Zipkin provides a propagation format (B3) and a data model (API v2: https://zipkin.io/zipkin-api/).  These models are open and for everyone to integrate with. 

If you are dead set on using the Jaeger UI instead of the Zipkin Lens UI while using Zipkin instrumentation you will have to find or write a Jaeger specific collector that listens on Kafka and understands Zipkin data model payloads.

the zipkin reporter is a final inner class (zipkin2.reporter.AsyncReporter.BoundedAsyncReporter), it is not convenient for us, so we copy these code, and create a new class,  and it supports span filtering now.  but ungracefully.
please use gitter, does https://github.com/openzipkin/brave/tree/master/brave#handling-finished-spans help ?

> please use gitter, does https://github.com/openzipkin/brave/tree/master/brave#handling-finished-spans help ?

thanks, it works.
By the way, the data is written into Kafka and stored in ES, not through HTTP

I use zuul to access spring cloud sleuth + Kafka + Zipkin.

cc @lambcode

@Dylan-haiji could you share a screenshot? If what you want is that zipkin displays the numnber of matching traces for a given search, that could be an expensive operation depending on the storage. Also, such observation belongs more to the metrics space IMO.

![zipkin](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37392164/72031056-2d1cd880-32c6-11ea-8a9c-e99fa10683c2.png)
As shown in the figure above, I think the display of this part can be optimized. For example, I now have 13 pieces of data, but if my facility displays 10 pieces of data per page, it will display 10 pieces, but if I set it to be more than the total number of data, it will now display the total number of pieces. I think it should always display the total number of pieces, so that the accurate results can be queried according to the conditions! How do you feel?

indexing is done differently in service of our HTTP api and the
constraints needed for it
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/tree/master/zipkin-storage/elasticsearch#query-indexing

no warranty, but you can look at this which discusses a feature
supported by Elasticsearch: secondary index template
https://gist.github.com/adriancole/1af1259102e7a2da1b3c9103565165d7

it was closed because custom servers are not supported, and the problem was phrased as a custom assembled server.

You can feel free to raise a PR to remove the NPE risk, which is maybe possible in default server, if someone changes some override property config.

Versions: OpenJDK 8, Zipkin-Server-2.19.2; self-signed JKS cert

Looks like needs copyright header update otherwise LGTM

I would recommend seeing if this can be merged because we should release zipkin soon due to code drift between armeria here and what's used in zipkin-gcp (possibly also zipkin-aws). Maybe update to latest armeria after deciding what to do here then cut a minor.
sorry I meant cut a patch
@adriancole Does it mean `CurrentTraceContext#wrap` should be fixed to attach the span to the last SERVER span in a case when the parent is CLIENT?

it could be a server span, or an intermediate (local) span.

the "folding" of seemingly duplicate clients is something that prevents, say duplicate http client middleware from appearing as multiple calls.

in any case we want to make sure that duplicate calls which are intentionally dupes are hierarchically sensible. callbacks certainly muddy this water. I think if you are referring to brave, which I think you are, there are some recent code merging to ensure that response callbacks reset to whatever the invocation span was.. regardless of whether that was a server, message consumer, or some intermediate span. https://github.com/openzipkin/brave/pull/1055

I agree with this Tommy's opinion.(https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/2906#issuecomment-556940485)
What do you think @adriancole ?

there are other data problems besides missing timestamps. I think before we just avoided things like divide by zero problems by skipping calculation of those spans. if no span has a timestamp we could error out. if only some are missing a timestamp we can still present the rest of the trace I think.

iotw, my opinion is to just avoid doing bad math. 

imho whether to warn or not is separate and optional, and if we decide to only warn about timestamps is that because we are only thinking about that? or we would only warn about timestamps and not things like backwards endpoints, flipped client/server or the various other problems? maybe just start with not bombing is better than having a one-off solution to one of many problems data can have.

thanks for the help. a few questions:

* what version constraints are there (if any) on prefetch
* what benefit do you expect to see
* what value would you use and when would you adjust it?

we will eventually need guidance in the javadoc and/or readme
I will open another pull request, because I found couple other performance related issues in Zipkin Server.
ok great. PS we are due to upgrade our rabbitmq driver version. If you are up to helping with that, much oblidged!

please revert the changes to the collector component and focus on the rabbitmq module instead. this is way too much change for what is needed. if you want to change the blocking mechanism in presence of the prefetch count that is ok but this is too much as it breaks api of other collectors

few other notes of interest:
* mysql is not intended for production use, and high throughput problems are expected in this storage
* there is a storage throttling feature in the server which may also help
Thank you for feedback, I will update the pull requests based on the comments.
By the way, performance issue was resolved with that fix. Performance test was done with 100K messages on a queue.

the asyncExecution thing which is to block the sender has been visited in other issues. you can look at the history and issues log to find out where we got to. there's also a design doc around the various problem space https://github.com/openzipkin/openzipkin.github.io/wiki/Collector-surge-and-error-handling

What I'm hoping is that you can lower the scope of your change so that it can be done with less design revisiting as what this PR did was change a base type. Also, it would probably be better to use gitter to discuss large design changes vs open multiple pull requests as the latter can send a flurry of notifications to watchers, some of whom have seen the same discussion many times and might prefer those issues looked at first before seeing another storm of the same content. https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin

we need someone to volunteer. there is no bench of people waiting for
tasks.. volunteer based. are you up for this?

@adriancole I have checked in the latest updates.
yes, Runnable::run would call span storage in the same thread. The 'async' parameter in accept method is used to determine whether to call enqueue (asynchronous) or execute (synchronous) on storage.

if your concern is storage throttling, there's already a solution for this. please see the server README on that. The change to the collector tier will not be accepted. You need to try the solutions that exist prior to new core level change. it took us months to work out the throttling thing.


particularly, note that you are using mysql which is specifically unsupported for prod anyway. I've asked a few times so far to keep this contained to the rabbitmq specific stuff. If you are able to do that, please revert the other things and we can focus on that. otherwise, if you are unwilling to you can always fork the project.
@adriancole Updated pull request as requested.

For context, one feedback we got last year from Haystack was that they too had a try button. So few people used it, that they had to pull the cord.

IMHO adding more "try" and "suggest" features is not an option anymore. We have to commit to the health of this project over a sense of perfection.
